content: Edited to improve the formatting and fix a few typos.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like it

I like this contribution.

My (small) issues are:

- N is fixed. It would be interessting to modify this number, with lower amount of transactions at first (for test purposes) and increasing this number after that.
- Your Transaction format is not mentionning the character £

Two remarks :
- You should give an example of transaction with a letter first (like "$ 25")
- I believe that your margin is 10 percent points and not 10%
Thanks, I added the full statement, and the rules to say when an account is considered fraudulent or not for this puzzle.

The statement must explain the task, you cannot simply rely on an external page for that.
Moreover, even knowing the law, what you mean by "seems fraudulent/regular" is not formally defined (you should explain how we are expected to evaluate to consistency with the law).

- Ah yes, forgot this one in example. Added.
- Yes you're right, I make it clearer in statement.

- I didn't added test with only few transaction because we need more samples to have a good estimation.

But anyway I'll add a first test with only 10 transactions.

EDIT: Mmh I don't know how to add at test at the beginning, it's appending to the end

- Yep, I'll add it, but in fact in could be any currencies. I expect that the first digit is selected with the regex /[1-9]/

Thank you for your answer.

For the first topic, having a N that can be different from one test to another will force the player to compute the percentage. There's no REAL need of a smaller test case for debug, it can be managed, but having a fixed value set as 1000, yet still putting it as input is strange. In your solution you compute the tolerance. When I've tested, I stored the benford values as 301, 176, 125, ... and tested value +- 100. It was lazy, but worked because N was a constant.

For the second topic, maybe just mentionning what you just said? That it could be any currencies...

"It was lazy, but worked because N was a constant."

Ah nice I understand. I changed the transaction numbers so that it should no longer work, and added a test with a regular account that fail if 1000 is hardcoded in average calculation
